bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, January 26, 1942

div1.p: Hench informs Kean that Lazear's niece took him to the old family home where he found letters from Lazear to his mother and other personal items. Hench notes that he has also found Agramonte's leave of absence papers indicating he left Cuba several days before Lazear died.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, January 26, 1942
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
January 26, 1942
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I was completely distressed by the fact that you were under the weather
when I was in Washington. I had been looking forward so long to seeing you and having
a nice long conversation with you. Indeed, I had spent considerable time collecting
material which I thought you would like to see and I had a list of questions which
I wanted to ask you. I brought along several documents and items for your perusal
but when I heard that you were having most of your teeth out and on top of it had
a little heart attack I realized that it was no time for me to visit you and tire you
out. I thought I might run around to say goodbye to you and Mrs. Kean the day after
our little party at the Willard but I had so many things to do that I was not able
to call on you and I knew that if I did it would just tantalize both of us to have
such a short conversation. However, all of this is a matter of fate and I will
try to write out my questions and send them to you so that you can answer them at
your leisure, I hope with the services of Mrs. Franck.

We were so honored to have you and Mrs. Kean dine with us and Mary and I
hope that the food went down alright. I should have liked to talk to you about the
movies. I imagine many of the old sites looked strange to you in their present con-
dition.

Did I tell you that Mrs. Gawne, Lazear's niece, took me to the old family
home outside of Baltimore and in the attic I found one hundred thirty-four letters of
Lazear to his mother, thirty-three of which were the letters he wrote to her from
Cuba, up to the very day of his last illness, September 18. We also found some inter-
esting old photographs of him never published, some of his school books and other
personal items of tremendous sentimental value. When I get a breather and can summarize
the material I got in the various governmental buildings, I will write you again in
more detail. Two of the most important things were the following:
1. I found Agramonte's formal leave of absence, indicating that he did actually
leave Cuba two or three days before Lazear died and was gone for two or three weeks.
This confirms General Truby's statements to me. I am having Agramonte's personal
record regarding that leave of absence photostated just for my own information.
2. The New York Academy notebook indicates that a man not listed on the Honor
Roll took a minor part, but nevertheless a part, in the Camp Lazear experiments. In
Reed's handwriting, the name “Springer” appears. He was inoculated with culex pungens
and of course did not get yellow fever. But the muster and pay rolls which I examined
indicated that he was ordered to Camp Lazear and was there for some time. I wonder whether
he was primarily sent as a cook or solely as a volunteer. In either event, Reed seems
to have used him for one control experiment, the significance of which later apparently
seemed so unimportant that Reed did not include him. I will send you his full name,
source of enlistment, etc. It will be interesting to look him up and I suspect that
General Kean
- 2 -
January 26, 1942
his relatives some time could make a claim for him--a more legitimate claim than
has been made for some others.

Enroute home, I had a nice visit with Lambert and with the mother of Forbes
in Chicago.

Let me again say what a pleasure it was to have you and Mrs. Kean at our
dinner.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely, Philip Hench
P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 “N” Street N. W.
Washington, D. C.
Did I send you the enclosed version of the YF talk?
